001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008
009import java.util.Random;
010
011/**
012 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
013 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
014 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
015 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
016 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
017 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
018 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
019 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
020 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
021 * <br>
022 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
023 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
024 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
025 */
026public class ColorTools {
027        /**
028         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
029         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
030         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
031         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
032         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
033         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
034         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
035         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
036         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
037         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
038         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
039         * <br>
040         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
041         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
042         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
043         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
044         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
045         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
046         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
047         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
048         *
049         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
050         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
051         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
052         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
053         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
054         */
055        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
056                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
057                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
058        }
059
060
061        /**
062         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
063         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. It
064         * correctly returns negative results when given negative inputs.
065         * <br>
066         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
067         * distributed between -512 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
068         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
069         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
070         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
071         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
072         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
073         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
074         * <br>
075         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
076         * @param x any finite float to find the cube root of
077         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
078         */
079        private static float cbrt(float x) {
080                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
081                final int sign = ix & 0x80000000;
082                ix &= 0x7FFFFFFF;
083                final float x0 = x;
084                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
085                ix += (ix>>>4);
086                ix = ix + (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0 | sign;
087                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
088                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
089                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
090                return x;
091        }
092
093        /**
094         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
095         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
096         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
097         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
098         */
099        private static float cube(final float x) {
100                return x * x * x;
101        }
102
103        /**
104         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
105         * Really just {@code component * component}.
106         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
107         * @return a linear version of component
108         */
109        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
110                return component * component;
111        }
112
113        /**
114         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
115         * Really just a float version of the square root of component.
116         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
117         * @return a non-linear version of component
118         */
119        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
120                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
121        }
122
123
124        /**
125         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
126         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
127         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
128         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
129         */
130        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
131        {
132                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
133                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
134                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
135                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
136                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
137                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
138                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
139                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
140                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
141                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
142                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
143        }
144
145        /**
146         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
147         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
148         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
149         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
150         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
151         */
152        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
153        {
154                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
155                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
156                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
157                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
158                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
159                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
160                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
161                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
162                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
163                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
164                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
165        }
166        /**
167         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
168         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
169         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
170         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
171         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
172         */
173        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
174        {
175                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
176                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
177                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
178                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
179                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
180                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
181                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
182                editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
183                editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
184                editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
185                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
186                return editing.clamp();
187        }
188
189        /**
190         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
191         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
192         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
193         */
194        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
195                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
196                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
197                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
198
199                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
200                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
201                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
202
203                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
204                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
205                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
206                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
207                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
208        }
209
210        /**
211         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
212         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
213         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
214         */
215        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
216                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
217                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
218                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
219                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
220                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
221                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
222                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
223                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
224                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
225                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
226                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
227                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
228        }
229
230        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
231        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
232        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
233        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
234
235        // shrunken multipliers:
236        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
237        //+0.9889992500 -1.2142961000 +0.2252968500
238        //+0.0129520185 +0.3913858800 -0.4043378800
239
240        /**
241         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
242         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
243         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
244         */
245        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
246                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
247                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
248                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
249                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
250                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
251                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
252                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
253                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
254                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
255                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
256                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
257        }
258
259        /**
260         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
261         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
262         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
263         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
264         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
265         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
266         */
267        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
268                r = forwardGamma(r);
269                g = forwardGamma(g);
270                b = forwardGamma(b);
271                final float l = cbrt(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
272                final float m = cbrt(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
273                final float s = cbrt(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
274                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
275                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
276                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
277                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
278                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
279        }
280
281        /**
282         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
283         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
284         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
285         */
286        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
287        {
288                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
289                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
290                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
291                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
292                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
293                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
294                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
295                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
296        }
297
298        /**
299         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
300         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
301         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
302         */
303        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
304        {
305                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
306                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
307                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
308                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
309                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
310                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
311                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
312                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
313        }
314
315        /**
316         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
317         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
318         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
319         */
320        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
321        {
322                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
323                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
324                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
325                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
326                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
327                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
328                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
329                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
330        }
331
332        /**
333         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
334         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
335         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
336         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
337         */
338        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
339        {
340                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
341        }
342
343        /**
344         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
345         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
346         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
347         */
348        public static float red(final float encoded)
349        {
350                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
351                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
352                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
353                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
354                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
355                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
356                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
357                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
358        }
359
360        /**
361         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
362         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
363         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
364         */
365        public static float green(final float encoded)
366        {
367                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
368                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
369                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
370                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
371                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
372                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
373                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
374                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
375        }
376
377        /**
378         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
379         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
380         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
381         */
382        public static float blue(final float encoded)
383        {
384                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
385                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
386                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
387                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
388                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
389                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
390                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
391                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
392        }
393
394        /**
395         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
396         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
397         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
398         */
399        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
400        {
401                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
402        }
403
404        /**
405         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
406         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
407         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma that colors that are perceptually
408         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its range depending on how colorful a value can be
409         * at its hue. That is, the most saturated color always has a saturation of 1, but if that color isn't perceptually
410         * very colorful, it could have a chroma that is somewhat lower than 1. I don't yet know the range of this function,
411         * other than it can't be negative, grayscale values have 0 chroma, and the most colorful values should be near 1,
412         * maybe as high as the square root of 2.
413         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
414         * @return a non-negative float that represents how colorful the given value is
415         */
416        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
417                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
418                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
419                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
420                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
421        }
422        /**
423         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
424         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
425         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
426         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
427         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
428         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
429         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
430         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
431         *
432         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
433         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
434         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
435         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
436         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
437         */
438        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
439                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
440                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
441                } else {
442                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
443                }
444        }
445
446        /**
447         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
448         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
449         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
450         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
451         */
452        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
453                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
454                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
455                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
456                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
457                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
458                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
459                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
460                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
461                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
462                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
463                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
464                float x, y, w;
465                if(g < b) {
466                        x = b;
467                        y = g;
468                }
469                else {
470                        x = g;
471                        y = b;
472                }
473                if(r < x) {
474                        w = r;
475                }
476                else {
477                        w = x;
478                        x = r;
479                }
480                return x - Math.min(w, y);
481        }
482
483        /**
484         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab.
485         * This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
486         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
487         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
488         */
489        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
490                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
491                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
492                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
493                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
494                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
495                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
496                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
497                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
498                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
499                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
500                float x, y, w;
501                if(g < b) {
502                        x = b;
503                        y = g;
504                }
505                else {
506                        x = g;
507                        y = b;
508                }
509                if(r < x) {
510                        w = r;
511                }
512                else {
513                        w = x;
514                        x = r;
515                }
516                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
517                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
518        }
519
520        /**
521         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
522         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
523         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
524         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
525         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
526         */
527        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
528                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
529                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
530                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
531                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
532                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
533                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
534                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
535                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
536                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
537                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
538                float x, y, z, w;
539                if(g < b) {
540                        x = b;
541                        y = g;
542                        z = -1f;
543                        w = 2f / 3f;
544                }
545                else {
546                        x = g;
547                        y = b;
548                        z = 0f;
549                        w = -1f / 3f;
550                }
551                if(r < x) {
552                        z = w;
553                        w = r;
554                }
555                else {
556                        w = x;
557                        x = r;
558                }
559                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
560                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
561        }
562
563        /**
564         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
565         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
566         *
567         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
568         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
569         */
570        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
571        {
572                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
573        }
574
575        /**
576         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
577         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
578         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
579         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
580         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
581         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
582         */
583        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
584        {
585                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
586        }
587
588        /**
589         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
590         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
591         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
592         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
593         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
594         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
595         */
596        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
597        {
598                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
599        }
600
601        /**
602         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, value, and
603         * opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Takes floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue,
604         * saturation, value, and opacity; these can be between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or
605         * encoded color with methods like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is
606         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
607         * value, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
608         * <br>
609         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
610         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
611         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
612         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
613         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
614         *
615         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
616         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
617         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
618         * @param value      -1f to 1f, the value/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
619         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
620         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
621         */
622        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float value, float opacity) {
623                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
624                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(value + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
625                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
626                if (L <= 0.001f)
627                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
628                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
629                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
630                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
631                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
632                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
633                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
634                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
635                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
636                float x, y, z, w;
637                if(g < b) {
638                        x = b;
639                        y = g;
640                        z = -1f;
641                        w = 2f / 3f;
642                }
643                else {
644                        x = g;
645                        y = b;
646                        z = 0f;
647                        w = -1f / 3f;
648                }
649                if(r < x) {
650                        z = w;
651                        w = r;
652                }
653                else {
654                        w = x;
655                        x = r;
656                }
657                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
658                float hue2 = Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
659                float sat2 = (x - L) / (Math.min(L, 1f - L) + 1e-10f);
660                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue2 + hue + 1 - (int)(hue2 + hue + 1), Math.min(Math.max(saturation + sat2, 0f), 1f), L, opacity));
661        }
662
663        /**
664         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
665         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
666         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
667         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
668         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
669         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
670         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
671         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
672         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
673         */
674        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
675                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
676                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
677        }
678
679        /**
680         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
681         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
682         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
683         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
684         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
685         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
686         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
687         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
688         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
689         */
690        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
691                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
692                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
693        }
694
695        /**
696         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
697         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
698         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
699         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
700         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
701         * alpha and L of start as-is.
702         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
703         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
704         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
705         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
706         */
707        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
708                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
709                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
710        }
711
712        /**
713         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
714         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
715         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
716         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
717         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
718         * L of start as-is.
719         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
720         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
721         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
722         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
723         */
724        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
725                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
726                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
727        }
728
729        /**
730         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
731         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
732         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
733         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
734         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
735         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
736         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
737         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
738         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
739         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
740         */
741        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
742                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
743                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
744        }
745
746        /**
747         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
748         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
749         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
750         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
751         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
752         * alpha and L of start as-is.
753         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
754         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
755         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
756         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
757         */
758        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
759                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
760                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
761        }
762
763        /**
764         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
765         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
766         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
767         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
768         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
769         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
770         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
771         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
772         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
773         */
774        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
775                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
776                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
777        }
778
779        /**
780         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
781         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
782         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
783         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
784         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
785         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
786         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
787         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
788         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
789         */
790        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
791                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
792                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
793        }
794
795        /**
796         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
797         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
798         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
799         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
800         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
801         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
802         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
803         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
804         */
805        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
806                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
807                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
808                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
809                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
810                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
811        }
812
813        /**
814         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
815         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
816         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only A and B, but higher values for
817         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
818         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change L somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
819         * then L won't change; alpha never changes.
820         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
821         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
822         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
823         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
824         */
825        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
826                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
827                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
828                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
829                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
830                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
831        }
832
833
834        /**
835         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
836         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
837         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
838         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
839         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
840         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
841         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
842         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
843         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
844         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
845         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
846         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
847         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
848         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
849         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
850         */
851        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
852        {
853                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
854                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
855                                L = (bits & 0xff),
856                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
857                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
858                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
859                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
860                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
861                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
862                        return mainColor;
863                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
864        }
865
866        /**
867         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
868         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
869         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
870         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
871         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
872         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
873         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
874         */
875        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
876                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
877                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
878                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
879                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
880                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
881                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
882                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
883        }
884
885        /**
886         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
887         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
888         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
889         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
890         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
891         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
892         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
893         * but only internally for measuring distance).
894         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
895         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
896         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
897         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
898         */
899        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
900                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
901                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
902                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
903                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
904                final float limit = variance * variance;
905                float dist, x, y, z;
906                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
907                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
908                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
909                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
910                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
911                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
912                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
913                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
914                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
915                }
916                return color;
917        }
918
919        /**
920         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
921         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
922         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
923         */
924        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
925        {
926                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
927                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
928                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
929                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
930                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
931                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
932                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
933
934                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
935                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
936                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
937                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
938                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
939                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
940        }
941        /**
942         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
943         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
944         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
945         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
946         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
947         */
948        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
949        {
950                A = (A - 0.5f) * 2f;
951                B = (B - 0.5f) * 2f;
952                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
953                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
954                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
955
956                final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
957//              if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) {
958//                      System.out.println("r out of gamut: " + r);
959//                      return false;
960//              }
961                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
962                final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
963//              if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) {
964//                      System.out.println("g out of gamut: " + g);
965//                      return false;
966//              }
967                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
968                final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
969//              if(b < 0f || b > 1.0f) {
970//                      System.out.println("b out of gamut: " + b);
971//                      return false;
972//              }
973//              return true;
974                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
975        }
976
977        /**
978         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
979         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
980         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
981         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
982         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
983         */
984        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
985                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
986                final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
987                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
988                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
989                float L2 = L, A2 = A, B2 = B;
990                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
991                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
992                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
993                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
994
995                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
996                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
997                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
998                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
999                                break;
1000                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1001                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
1002                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
1003                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
1004                }
1005                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1006        }
1007
1008        /**
1009         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
1010         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
1011         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1012         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1013         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1014         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
1015         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1016         */
1017        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1018                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1019        }
1020        /**
1021         * Iteratively checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if it
1022         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
1023         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1024         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1025         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1026         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1027         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given Oklab color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
1028         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1029         */
1030        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1031                float L2 = L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1032                float A2 = A = Math.min(Math.max((A - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
1033                float B2 = B = Math.min(Math.max((B - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
1034                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1035                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1036                        final float l = cube(L2 + 0.3963377774f * A2 + 0.2158037573f * B2);
1037                        final float m = cube(L2 - 0.1055613458f * A2 - 0.0638541728f * B2);
1038                        final float s = cube(L2 - 0.0894841775f * A2 - 1.2914855480f * B2);
1039
1040                        final float r = +4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s;
1041                        final float g = -1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s;
1042                        final float b = -0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s;
1043                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1044                                break;
1045                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1046                        L2 = MathUtils.lerp(0.63f, L, progress);
1047                        A2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, A, progress);
1048                        B2 = MathUtils.lerp(0, B, progress);
1049                }
1050                return oklab(L2, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1051        }
1052
1053        /**
1054         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1055         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1056         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1057         */
1058        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1059                float L = random.nextFloat();
1060                float A = random.nextFloat();
1061                float B = random.nextFloat();
1062                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1063                        L = random.nextFloat();
1064                        A = random.nextFloat();
1065                        B = random.nextFloat();
1066                }
1067                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1068        }
1069}
